President'sInaugural eisgall To Lead Symphony
Set For Next Friday In Series' Second Concert
Five special greetings will be presented to Milton
Stover Eisenhower next Friday (Feb. 22) when he is
installed as eighth president of The Johns Hopkins University during Commemoration Day ceremonies which will
mark the university's 81st anniversary.
The ceremony, scheduled for Shriver Hall on the
Homewood Campus at 11 a.m., will include welcoming
Speeches by the following Hopkins representatives:
Mr. Lewis Sank, president of the Student Council;
11/Ir. William Hillis, graduate student of the School of Medicine; Mr. Eli Frank, Jr., president of the Alumni Association; and Dr. Abel Wolman, professor of sanitary engineering.
Welcome By Ensor
Welcoming Dr. Eisenhower on
behalf of colleges and universities in Maryland will be Dr. Lowell Ensor, president of Western
Maryland College.
Dr. Eisenhower, who will be
Officially installed as president
by Mr. Carlyle Barton, president
Of the Board of Trustees, will
deliver a major address.
Other featured guests to appeat on the program include
The Right Reverend Nobel C.
Powell, - Episcopal Bishop of
Maryland; Dr. Lowell J. Reed,
President Emeritus of Johns
lioPkins; Dr. Eric Walker, president of Pennsylvania State UniversitY, and Thomas D'Alesanclro, Mayor of Baltimore.
Marshals, Honor Guard
Marshals for the program will
b.e Dr. C. Vann Woodward, Dr.
William McElroy, Dr. Ferdinand
Hamburger and Dr. Edward

Maumenee.

Junior Prom
At Alcazar
• The annual Junior Prom will
take place Saturday evening,
March 2, between 9-1 at the
Alcazar, according to co-chairMen Fred Rosenbloom and Mason Sisk.
The music will be provided by
till Maisel and his orchestra.
An admission of $2 per couple,
reduced from former prices of $4
because of employment of a
smaller band than was originally
Planned, will be collected at the
door. Tickets will also be sold
each day at noon in Levering
Rail. The dress will be semiformal and corsages are not to be
worn.

Tops Senior List
For Julie Week

Ralph Marterie was the top
choice of seniors to play at this
year's Senior Prom, in a poll of
the class conducted earlier this
year, June Week chairman Bob
Mitgang announced this week.
The poll also revealed that the
class prefers a Bull Roast to a

Condon; trailing him were Stan

The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra will present the
second in a series of three concerts Sunday at 4 p.m. in
Shriver Hall, with Mr. Hugo Weisgall conducting.
The program this Sunday will open with Christoph
Gluck's Overture, Iphigenia in Aulis. This will be followed by Johann Sebastian Bach's Brandenburg Concerto
No. 3, and by William Schuman's New England Tripytch.
The latter selection has never been performed in Baltimore
before now. The concert will conclude with Johannes
Brahms' Symphony No. 4.
Guest conductor Weisgall is the director of the Johns
Hopkins Orchestra and is a composer of several musical
'scores and operas.

been impressed with the difficulty of being accepted in a university to such an extent that

Multiple Applications

caused an apparently decreasing

Three Hungarian refugees have been granted full scholarships, including room and board, at Johns Hopkins. Their names
are being withheld because of political reasons.Two are graduate students in the science department. Plans are now underway to supply
the students with spending money and a goal of $320 has been
set by the Student Council. THE NEWS-LETTER has already
contributed $50 and other organizations and individuals on campus
are being solicited.

"Like having your own $3,0001000 business"
Joseph S. Manning graduated in 1950
from Wesleyan University with a B.A. degree and a major in Bio-Chemistry. But
chemistry, he decided, was not to be his
career. He became intrigued, instead, by
the opportunities in the telephone business, and joined New York Telephone
Company in 1951,
Today Joe Manning is Business Office
Manager in Parkchester, Bronx, New
York. In this position he is responsible
for about 27,000 telephone accounts
which bill some $250,000 a month. 35
people work under him.
"It's like having your own $3,000,000
business," Joe says."And it's pretty much

an independent operation, which I enjoy.
I'm in charge of all business office functions, and of personnel training and development. I also spend a lot Of time out
with my customers, making sure that they
have the telephone service they want and
rived. It's an absorbing job.
"The phenomenal growth of the business is one of the reasons why advancement opportunities are so good in the
telephone company. Since 1943, for example, the number of telephones in our
area has almost tripled. Growth such as
this, going on all over the country, makes
the telephone business especially attractive to anyone seeking a career with a
future."

Bell Telephone Companies offer many interesting
career opportunities, as do Bell Telephone
Laboratories, Western Electric and Sandia Corporation. Your placement officer has more information about all Bell System Companies.

NEWS-LETTEL

S To Distribute Laurels
For Literary Achievement
The Tudor and Stuart Club is
offering prizes totaling $100 for
"outstanding undergraduate literary efforts during the current
year" in its annual literary contest, according to Executive Secretary Mark Doyle.
As a part of its program to
stimulate literary interest, the
Tudor and Stuart Club will
award prizes of $40 for the best
creative literary work, $40 for
the best research essay dealing
with some aspect of English
speaking civilization, and $20 for
the best student library entered
in the contest.
Prose, poetry and dramatic
works will be accepted in the
creative writing division of the
contest. The research papers,
which must be no more than

5,000 words in length, will be
judged on the bases of originality of thought, effectiveness of
presentation, and documentation. They must necessarily be
of a scientific or technical nature.
A student submitting a library
must include a brief statement
of his general aims in building a
library together with a list of
books which he believes are representative of his library.

Notice
All members of the University
interested in organizing and participating in the annual Student-Faculty Talent Show, please
contact Bob Baensch.

Spectators Must
Cease Smoking
At Athletic Events
The Athletic Department has
issued an announcement requesting that spectators at all athletic
events held in the Homewood
Gymnasium refrain from smoking in the stands.
The Student Cotincil's Gentleman's Code Committee is presently checking into the rule concerning smoking in the gymnasium, and will 'report to the
Council to make a decision on
how to enforce the Athletic Department's ruling. Meanwhile,
the Athletic Department requests that spectators comply
with the ruling.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, FEB. 15, 1957

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE SEVEN

• Increased Circulation And comments From Students
Attributed To Altered Presentation By 'Weekly'Staff
(Continued from Page 6)
assigned to fit the nature and
interest of the reporters.
Handkerchief Center
"Beau Ties" consists of announcements of marriages, engagements, and pinnings and was
cited as a "throw back to the
Older style . . but almost unavoidable, in a girls school."
A constant plea from one of
the staff members, "Does anyone
know some jokes—clean jokes
that can be published in a girls'
newspaper?" aroused our curiosity until Suzanne explained that
Jokes and "facts" (Passaic, New
Jersey, produc-s_three-fourths of
the world's handkerchiefs) are
used to fill small empty spots in
the paper. They are used only
as a . last resort on Tuesday
nights, as is "Beau Ties."
The sports section of the
Coucher Weekly, as contradistinct to its alter-cgo in the
News-Letter, is the shortest and
"least read" portion of the paper.
Its usual contents is only three
or four stories; and• it serves
"primarily as publicity for the
Goucher Athletic Association."
Most of the articles are concerned with events not staged
on the Goucher campus but with
"sports played away."
When stories are written on
home games, the sports staff will
frequently attempt to inject a
• note of criticism into their art- cies. • Highlighting the sports section for the past few weeks has
t. been a sports-feature on the his' torY of various athletic events.
One Big Family
The average size of the Weekly
Is four to six pages, and Suzanne
commented that the actual work
Is "very little departmentalized."
Peggy stated that the frequent
Work nights and the compactness of both the staff and the
Paper itself allow "a fairly close
relationship between myself and
the rest of the girls."
"One
great advantage of
smallness and working together
Closely," ,she said, "is a singular
and integrated policy" which is
Present throughout the paper.
"We are able to color our articles in accord with this general
Policy." She feels that the new
Presentation gives a writer a
Much better chance to display
"her own ifiventiveness and originality ... We aren't hampered
by its (the former style's) rigidity any longer."
A majority of the members of
the Weekly's staff are underclassmen. Peggy is one of two
seniors on the entire paper. The
various department editors are
juniors and sophomores, with the
more important posts being held
by the third year students. Most
of the writing is done by sophomores and freshmen; and within
the last two weeks the Weekly
has added fourteen new members
to its staff.
Generally, the editorials are
Written by Peggy, but other
members of the Editorial Board
offer frequent suggestions and
criticisms and will often write
the editorials themselves if "they
have a good idea that they want
to work on."
Vox Populi
The new presentation has created a great deal of previously
absent student comment on the
Paper. "As of rather recently,"
Peggy commented,"we have been
looked upon as rabble-rousers."
Faculty commentaries on the
revision of the Weekly have been
"fairly reserved ... They (faculty members) were never particularly critical of us . . . They
offer a great many suggestions
. . and we frequently cooperate
with them by withholding stories
at their request."
Copies of the Weekly are distributed free of charge each week
on the Goucher campus, and one
of the staff members commented
that distribution has increased
since the alteration in policy,
contending that this policy has
increased both the circulation

and the interest on campus.
Since making the change, the
Weekly has received five or six
letters from students each week,
where formerly they might have
received as few as one per month.
The content of the letters varies
from high praise to condemnation, and most of them discuss
the .alteration in policy. "None
of them are in the middle.,"
Peggy said, "I don't think that
they know what they want; but
at least we know that the girls
are reading the paper now."
The defamatory letters, Peggy
explained, show that the writers
are a "little stunned from a stint
of comment on a usually quiet
campus."

—GINNIS

Three work nights each week, and there is still space to be filled on Tuesday evenings at 11:00 p.m.

Jays o Seek League Win

"They are a very dangerous
ball club." said Coach Ross Sachs
of Hampden-Sydney, whom the
Johns Hopkins varsity basketball team meets tomorrow night
at 8:45 at Homewood Gym.

BY AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor

Hampden-Sydney is the only
team thus far that has beaten
Mount Saint Mary's-, the current leaders of the Mason-Dixon
Conference. Described by Coach
Sachs as a team with both height
and speed, they have several
players over six feet five inches.
In previous encounters Hampden-Sydney has used a zone defense.

When the Blue Jay varsity cagers take the court tonight against the Tigers of Hampden-Sydney College,
they will stand at the cross-roads of the 1956-57 season.
A victory would go a long way toward sending the Jays
down the road to the Mason-Dixon Tournament, while a
loss would probably keep them from entering the eightteam event for the third consecutive campaign.
The sophomore studded team has come a long way
since the opening of the present campaign. As the season
started, the squad was lacking three of last season's starters, and the outlook was bleak.

Face Conquerors Of Kingpins

However, is the sophomores gained game experience,
the Jay five constantly improved to the point where tomorrow night they will have a good chance "of upending
the team that handed Mt. St. Mary's their only defeat of
the season.
The improvement of the Jays was demonstrated in
the Washington & Lee, Loyola and Western Maryland
games. Although the Jays only defeated the Terrors, the
improvement was evident. The Jays outplayed Loyola for
39 minutes and the loss was a heartbreaker.
Experience, Attack And Defense

We believe that the steady improvement of the cagers
can be attributed to three chief factors. First, the experience gained by the sophs is now bearing fruit and they are
making fewer mistakes. The second factor is the well
rounded attack the Jays are now sporting. Bill Civiletti,
Ed Bernstein, Jim Spitznas and Dick Weinstein have all
been taking turns at leading the Hopkins scorers. The last
but not least of the factors concerns the new zone defense
that the Jays are employing. It is unique and seems to
throw the opposition off stride.
An interesting and noteworthy set of statistics, coinpiled by John Bridgers, appears on page nine which can
not escape our comment. The 5.176 average compiled by
the Jay gridders may dent the minds of the individuals,
who believe that because one plays a sport, he will necessarily.be an academic failure. The fact- that none of the
gridders received a failure while facing the stresses of a
championship season is indeed not to be passed over without notice.

In speaking of the Western
Maryland game, coach Sachs
said, "I consider anything a good
effort up there (at Westminster),
since they usually give us a lot
of trouble. I think Weinstein has
improved in his over all play and
Jim Spitznas has definitely improved offensively. Jerry Gottlieb has been dropped from the
squad for disciplinary reasons."
Of the Jays' two games fol-,
lowing mid-term, Sachs said,
"Although we lost both of them,
I felt that we played two good
games against Washington and
Lee and Loyola."

—Ginnis

The Mules are in the throes of

seen a victory since last season.
Hopkins coach, Cal Schlick, is
looking past tomorrow's match
Which he expects to be "a real
good" one.

Schlick is a little disappointed
because of the inconsistent efforts displayed by the Hopkins
swordsmen. The Jay tutor feels
that some of the inconsistency is
due to the several changes he
has made and to the youth of
his squad. Schlick has moved
Bill Weiss from foil to epee and
Fred Rosenbloom from foil to
sabre.

respectively.

Five special greetings will be presented to Milton
Stover Eisenhower next Friday (Feb. 22) when he is
installed as eighth president of The Johns Hopkins University during Commemoration Day ceremonies which will
mark the university's 81st anniversary.
The ceremony, scheduled for Shriver Hall on the
Homewood Campus at 11 a.m., will include welcoming
Speeches by the following Hopkins representatives:
Mr. Lewis Sank, president of the Student Council;
11/Ir. William Hillis, graduate student of the School of Medicine; Mr. Eli Frank, Jr., president of the Alumni Association; and Dr. Abel Wolman, professor of sanitary engineering.

"Like having your own $3,0001000 business"
Joseph S. Manning graduated in 1950
from Wesleyan University with a B.A. degree and a major in Bio-Chemistry. But
chemistry, he decided, was not to be his
career. He became intrigued, instead, by
the opportunities in the telephone business, and joined New York Telephone
Company in 1951,
Today Joe Manning is Business Office
Manager in Parkchester, Bronx, New
York. In this position he is responsible
for about 27,000 telephone accounts
which bill some $250,000 a month. 35
people work under him.
"It's like having your own $3,000,000

S To Distribute Laurels
For Literary Achievement
The Tudor and Stuart Club is
offering prizes totaling $100 for
"outstanding undergraduate literary efforts during the current
year" in its annual literary contest, according to Executive Secretary Mark Doyle.
As a part of its program to
stimulate literary interest, the
Tudor and Stuart Club will
award prizes of $40 for the best
creative literary work, $40 for
the best research essay dealing
with some aspect of English
speaking civilization, and $20 for
the best student library entered
in the contest.
Prose, poetry and dramatic
works will be accepted in the
creative writing division of the
contest. The research papers,
which must be no more than

5,000 words in length, will be
judged on the bases of originality of thought, effectiveness of
presentation, and documentation. They must necessarily be
of a scientific or technical nature.
A student submitting a library
must include a brief statement
of his general aims in building a
library together with a list of
books which he believes are representative of his library.

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE SEVEN

• Increased Circulation And comments From Students
Attributed To Altered Presentation By 'Weekly'Staff
(Continued from Page 6)
assigned to fit the nature and
interest of the reporters.
Handkerchief Center
"Beau Ties" consists of announcements of marriages, engagements, and pinnings and was
cited as a "throw back to the
Older style . . but almost unavoidable, in a girls school."
A constant plea from one of
the staff members, "Does anyone
know some jokes—clean jokes
that can be published in a girls'
newspaper?" aroused our curiosity until Suzanne explained that
Jokes and "facts" (Passaic, New
Jersey, produc-s_three-fourths of
the world's handkerchiefs) are
used to fill small empty spots in
the paper. They are used only
as a . last resort on Tuesday
nights, as is "Beau Ties."
The sports section of the
Coucher Weekly, as contradistinct to its alter-cgo in the
News-Letter, is the shortest and
"least read" portion of the paper.
Its usual contents is only three
or four stories; and• it serves
"primarily as publicity for the
Goucher Athletic Association."
Most of the articles are concerned with events not staged
on the Goucher campus but with
"sports played away."
When stories are written on
home games, the sports staff will
frequently attempt to inject a
• note of criticism into their art- cies. • Highlighting the sports section for the past few weeks has
t. been a sports-feature on the his' torY of various athletic events.
One Big Family
The average size of the Weekly
Is four to six pages, and Suzanne
commented that the actual work
Is "very little departmentalized."
Peggy stated that the frequent
Work nights and the compactness of both the staff and the
Paper itself allow "a fairly close
relationship between myself and
the rest of the girls."
"One
great advantage of
smallness and working together
Closely," ,she said, "is a singular
and integrated policy" which is
Present throughout the paper.
"We are able to color our articles in accord with this general
Policy." She feels that the new
Presentation gives a writer a
Much better chance to display
"her own ifiventiveness and originality ... We aren't hampered
by its (the former style's) rigidity any longer."
A majority of the members of
the Weekly's staff are underclassmen. Peggy is one of two
seniors on the entire paper. The
various department editors are
juniors and sophomores, with the
more important posts being held
by the third year students. Most
of the writing is done by sophomores and freshmen; and within
the last two weeks the Weekly
has added fourteen new members
to its staff.
Generally, the editorials are
Written by Peggy, but other
members of the Editorial Board
offer frequent suggestions and
criticisms and will often write
the editorials themselves if "they
have a good idea that they want
to work on."
Vox Populi
The new presentation has created a great deal of previously
absent student comment on the
Paper. "As of rather recently,"
Peggy commented,"we have been
looked upon as rabble-rousers."
Faculty commentaries on the
revision of the Weekly have been
"fairly reserved ... They (faculty members) were never particularly critical of us . . . They
offer a great many suggestions
. . and we frequently cooperate
with them by withholding stories
at their request."
Copies of the Weekly are distributed free of charge each week
on the Goucher campus, and one
of the staff members commented
that distribution has increased
since the alteration in policy,
contending that this policy has
increased both the circulation

and the interest on campus.
Since making the change, the
Weekly has received five or six
letters from students each week,
where formerly they might have
received as few as one per month.
The content of the letters varies
from high praise to condemnation, and most of them discuss
the .alteration in policy. "None
of them are in the middle.,"
Peggy said, "I don't think that
they know what they want; but
at least we know that the girls
are reading the paper now."
The defamatory letters, Peggy
explained, show that the writers
are a "little stunned from a stint
of comment on a usually quiet
campus."

—GINNIS

Three work nights each week, and there is still space to be filled on Tuesday evenings at 11:00 p.m.

Clings to the
road like a
stripe ofpaint!
The '57 Chevy can give lessons
on taking curves and holding the
road to just about any car going.
Few cars at any price are so
beautifully balanced and so
smooth, sure and solid in action.
A car has to have a special kind of
build and balance to keep curves
under control. And nobody outdoes
Chevrolet in that department! It

Jays o Seek League Win

"They are a very dangerous
ball club." said Coach Ross Sachs
of Hampden-Sydney, whom the
Johns Hopkins varsity basketball team meets tomorrow night
at 8:45 at Homewood Gym.

BY AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor

Hampden-Sydney is the only
team thus far that has beaten
Mount Saint Mary's-, the current leaders of the Mason-Dixon
Conference. Described by Coach
Sachs as a team with both height
and speed, they have several
players over six feet five inches.
In previous encounters Hampden-Sydney has used a zone defense.

When the Blue Jay varsity cagers take the court tonight against the Tigers of Hampden-Sydney College,
they will stand at the cross-roads of the 1956-57 season.
A victory would go a long way toward sending the Jays
down the road to the Mason-Dixon Tournament, while a
loss would probably keep them from entering the eightteam event for the third consecutive campaign.
The sophomore studded team has come a long way
since the opening of the present campaign. As the season
started, the squad was lacking three of last season's starters, and the outlook was bleak.

Face Conquerors Of Kingpins

However, is the sophomores gained game experience,
the Jay five constantly improved to the point where tomorrow night they will have a good chance "of upending
the team that handed Mt. St. Mary's their only defeat of
the season.
The improvement of the Jays was demonstrated in
the Washington & Lee, Loyola and Western Maryland
games. Although the Jays only defeated the Terrors, the
improvement was evident. The Jays outplayed Loyola for
39 minutes and the loss was a heartbreaker.
Experience, Attack And Defense

We believe that the steady improvement of the cagers
can be attributed to three chief factors. First, the experience gained by the sophs is now bearing fruit and they are
making fewer mistakes. The second factor is the well
rounded attack the Jays are now sporting. Bill Civiletti,
Ed Bernstein, Jim Spitznas and Dick Weinstein have all
been taking turns at leading the Hopkins scorers. The last
but not least of the factors concerns the new zone defense
that the Jays are employing. It is unique and seems to
throw the opposition off stride.
An interesting and noteworthy set of statistics, coinpiled by John Bridgers, appears on page nine which can
not escape our comment. The 5.176 average compiled by
the Jay gridders may dent the minds of the individuals,
who believe that because one plays a sport, he will necessarily.be an academic failure. The fact- that none of the
gridders received a failure while facing the stresses of a
championship season is indeed not to be passed over without notice.

In speaking of the Western
Maryland game, coach Sachs
said, "I consider anything a good
effort up there (at Westminster),
since they usually give us a lot
of trouble. I think Weinstein has
improved in his over all play and
Jim Spitznas has definitely improved offensively. Jerry Gottlieb has been dropped from the
squad for disciplinary reasons."
Of the Jays' two games fol-,
lowing mid-term, Sachs said,
"Although we lost both of them,
I felt that we played two good
games against Washington and
Lee and Loyola."

—Ginnis

looking past tomorrow's match
Which he expects to be "a real
good" one.

swordsmen. The Jay tutor feels

due to the several changes he

The Applied Physics Laboratory
(APL)of The Johns Hopkins University, one of the country's leading R & D organizations, affords
young men of above-average skill
and originality unusual opportunities for rapid progress toward (1)
professional specialization, or (2)
technical administration or operations.
APL is unique in that it is
neither an industrial nor an academic organization. Instead it is a
composite of both, having drawn
freely from the methodologies of
each. Because. of this, APL has
managed to keep in the vanguard,
having pioneered the proximity
fuze, the first supersonic ramjet
engine,and the missiles TERRIER,
TALOS and TARTAR. APL has
sole responsibility for the Navy's
Bumblebee guided missile program, directs the work Of 21

associate Atd sub-contractors,
among them leading universities
and industrial organization.
Location & Facilities
As a result its staff members

enjoy an interchange of ideas with
members of these various organizations; have access to their facilities, in addition to the wealth of
equipment available at APL's
350,000 sq. ft. laboratories midway between Washington, D. C.
and Baltimore, and in Silver
Spring, Md. In this environment
men of originality and talent
flourish. Salaries compare favorably with those of other R & D
organizations; staff benefits are
manifold, including a strong program of financial assistance for
graduate work. For full information contact your Placement Officer or write: Professional Staff
